body:
:O 

Seems there's some issue with OpenGL drivers. They unfortunately don't all support the same features. Are you running Mac/Linux? What kind of GPU?

I am running on Linux. For the GPU, I don't really know.

If I execute `sudo lshw -C display`, I get: 

```
  *-display                 
       description: VGA compatible controller
       product: 4th Gen Core Processor Integrated Graphics Controller
       vendor: Intel Corporation
       physical id: 2
       bus info: pci@0000:00:02.0
       version: 06
       width: 64 bits
       clock: 33MHz
       capabilities: msi pm vga_controller bus_master cap_list rom
       configuration: driver=i915 latency=0
       resources: irq:30 memory:f7800000-f7bfffff memory:e0000000-efffffff ioport:f000(size=64) memory:c0000-dffff
```

I don't know if it helps...

Yes that is useful. Your GPU is the one that comes built into your Intel CPU. The driver you use is probably the default one that comes with Linux.

I added some extra debugging code which will hopefully give us more information about the specific frame buffer error that happened. Could you do a `git pull` and run it again?

```
gym-miniworld$ ./manual_control.py --env-name MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-CollectHealth-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-FourRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Maze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-MazeS3-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-OneRoom-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-PutNext-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-TMaze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-ThreeRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-WallGap-v0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./manual_control.py", line 23, in <module>
    env = gym.make(args.env_name)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 167, in make
    return registry.make(id)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 119, in make
    env = spec.make()
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 86, in make
    env = cls(**self._kwargs)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/envs/hallway.py", line 19, in __init__
    **kwargs
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/miniworld.py", line 517, in __init__
    self.obs_fb = FrameBuffer(obs_width, obs_height, 8)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/opengl.py", line 196, in __init__
    assert res == GL_FRAMEBUFFER_COMPLETE, FB_ERROR_ENUMS.get(res, res)
AssertionError: GL_FRAMEBUFFER_UNSUPPORTED
```

Okay, might be making progress :)

I added an extra check. Could you please try running it once more?

Then, if it doesn't work, can you try:
1. Setting `num_samples = 1` before the try block: https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/gym_miniworld/opengl.py#L132
2. Replacing this line with just `assert False`: https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/gym_miniworld/opengl.py#L134 

I'd like to know if either of these fix the problem. Sorry this is taking multiple iterations to debug.

This works when I do the modifications 1. and 2. you suggest.

**Edit :** This also works when I do only 1. 

However, when I close the window, the script doesn't end. I don't know if it is the expected behavior but it is not the behavior in MiniGrid

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5437552/48280303-83d51b00-e453-11e8-9d07-32d9691dd5ba.png)

I keep trying to make your repository working for mine, but now, I have a new bug:

```
torch-rl$ python -m scripts.train --algo ppo --env MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-CollectHealth-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-FourRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Maze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-MazeS3-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-OneRoom-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-PutNext-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-TMaze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-ThreeRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-WallGap-v0
/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/scripts/train.py --algo ppo --env MiniWorld-Hallway-v0

Namespace(algo='ppo', batch_size=256, clip_eps=0.2, discount=0.99, entropy_coef=0.01, env='MiniWorld-Hallway-v0', epochs=4, frames=10000000,frames_per_proc=None, gae_lambda=0.95, instr=False, log_interval=1, lr=0.0007, max_grad_norm=0.5, mem=False, model=None, optim_alpha=0.99, optim_eps=1e-05, procs=16, recurrence=1, save_interval=0, seed=1, tb=False, value_loss_coef=0.5)

loading texture "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/textures/concrete_1.png"
loading texture "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/textures/floor_tiles_bw_1.png"
loading texture "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/textures/concrete_tiles_1.png"
Model successfully created

ACModel(
  (image_conv): Sequential(
    (0): Conv2d(3, 16, kernel_size=(2, 2), stride=(1, 1))
    (1): ReLU()
    (2): MaxPool2d(kernel_size=(2, 2), stride=(2, 2), padding=0, dilation=1, ceil_mode=False)
    (3): Conv2d(16, 32, kernel_size=(2, 2), stride=(1, 1))
    (4): ReLU()
    (5): Conv2d(32, 64, kernel_size=(2, 2), stride=(1, 1))
    (6): ReLU()
  )
  (actor): Sequential(
    (0): Linear(in_features=63936, out_features=64, bias=True)
    (1): Tanh()
    (2): Linear(in_features=64, out_features=3, bias=True)
  )
  (critic): Sequential(
    (0): Linear(in_features=63936, out_features=64, bias=True)
    (1): Tanh()
    (2): Linear(in_features=64, out_features=1, bias=True)
  )
)

CUDA available: False

i965: Failed to submit batchbuffer: Invalid argument
i965: Failed to submit batchbuffer: Invalid argument
i965: Failed to submit batchbuffer: Invalid argument
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/scripts/train.py", line 152, in <module>
    logs = algo.update_parameters()
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/algos/ppo.py", line 32, in update_parameters
    exps, logs = self.collect_experiences()
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/algos/base.py", line 136, in collect_experiences
    obs, reward, done, _ = self.env.step(action.cpu().numpy())
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/utils/penv.py", line 50, in step
    results = zip(*[(obs, reward, done, info)] + [local.recv() for local in self.locals])
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/utils/penv.py", line 50, in <listcomp>
    results = zip(*[(obs, reward, done, info)] + [local.recv() for local in self.locals])
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/connection.py", line 250, in recv
    buf = self._recv_bytes()
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/connection.py", line 407, in _recv_bytes
    buf = self._recv(4)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/connection.py", line 383, in _recv
    raise EOFError
EOFError
```

It seems there is a problem with multiprocessing and OpenGL, especially when the subprocesses try to communicate with the parent.

Great that you got the graphics working. I will try to come up with a cleaner fix for that.

For the second issue, thankfully, I already have a workaround. You have to set the fork method to 'forkserver':

https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/pytorch-a2c-ppo-acktr/vec_env/subproc_vec_env.py#L2
https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/pytorch-a2c-ppo-acktr/vec_env/subproc_vec_env.py#L39

This changes something in the way resources are shared between subprocesses I believe.

I now have this bug:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/scripts/train.py", line 138, in <module>
    args.optim_eps, args.clip_eps, args.epochs, args.batch_size, preprocess_obss)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/algos/ppo.py", line 18, in __init__
    value_loss_coef, max_grad_norm, recurrence, preprocess_obss, reshape_reward)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/algos/base.py", line 49, in __init__
    self.env = ParallelEnv(envs)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/torch-rl/torch_rl/torch_rl/utils/penv.py", line 35, in __init__
    p.start()
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/process.py", line 105, in start
    self._popen = self._Popen(self)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/context.py", line 223, in _Popen
    return _default_context.get_context().Process._Popen(process_obj)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/context.py", line 291, in _Popen
    return Popen(process_obj)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_forkserver.py", line 35, in __init__
    super().__init__(process_obj)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_fork.py", line 19, in __init__
    self._launch(process_obj)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/popen_forkserver.py", line 47, in _launch
    reduction.dump(process_obj, buf)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/reduction.py", line 60, in dump
    ForkingPickler(file, protocol).dump(obj)
ValueError: ctypes objects containing pointers cannot be pickled
```

I did some searches but I can't identify exactly what I send and that is not pickable.
This I'm not sure about. Are you trying to pickle the whole env or something?

@lcswillems I added a check to the frame buffer to automatically get the maximum number of samples supported. Does this allow you to run `manual_control.py` without modifications?

Also fixed the window closing issue.

No, it doesn't work... Here is the error:

```
gym-miniworld$ ./manual_control.py --env-name MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-CollectHealth-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-FourRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Hallway-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-Maze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-MazeS3-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-OneRoom-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-PutNext-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-TMaze-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-ThreeRooms-v0
Registered env: MiniWorld-WallGap-v0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./manual_control.py", line 23, in <module>
    env = gym.make(args.env_name)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 167, in make
    return registry.make(id)
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 119, in make
    env = spec.make()
  File "/home/lcswillems/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/gym/envs/registration.py", line 86, in make
    env = cls(**self._kwargs)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/envs/hallway.py", line 19, in __init__
    **kwargs
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/miniworld.py", line 517, in __init__
    self.obs_fb = FrameBuffer(obs_width, obs_height, 8)
  File "/mnt/Data/Documents/Education/2017 2018 - M1/Stage/Code/gym-miniworld/gym_miniworld/opengl.py", line 208, in __init__
    assert res == GL_FRAMEBUFFER_COMPLETE, FB_ERROR_ENUMS.get(res, res)
AssertionError: GL_FRAMEBUFFER_UNSUPPORTED
```

In the `opengl.py` file, you have `);` at the end of some lines.
@lcswillems Ok, I moved the success check into the try block so that it always retries without multisampling if it fails. Does `manual_control` run without changes now?

> Great that you got the graphics working. I will try to come up with a cleaner fix for that.
> 
> For the second issue, thankfully, I already have a workaround. You have to set the fork method to 'forkserver':
> 
> https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/pytorch-a2c-ppo-acktr/vec_env/subproc_vec_env.py#L2
> https://github.com/maximecb/gym-miniworld/blob/master/pytorch-a2c-ppo-acktr/vec_env/subproc_vec_env.py#L39
> 
> This changes something in the way resources are shared between subprocesses I believe.

A problem with this modifications is that it doesn't make MiniGrid working anymore.
